Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Hazard Analysis of Deadly Mud Flows at Mt. Ruapehu Volcano, New Zealand
Award.AbstractNarration:
Volcanic mud flows, termed lahars, are among the deadliest of volcanic phenomena, having killed 40,000 people worldwide since the late 1700?s. On steep volcanoes, lahars can exceed speeds of 200 km/hr, traveling over 100 km and growing up to 10 times their initial size as they ensnare loose soil and rock. The active Mt. Ruapehu Volcano, located on the north island of New Zealand, is one of the world?s most regular producers of lahars due to the presence of a lake in its crater rim. Since 1861, 22 lahars have occurred at this volcano, most of which initiate when water overflows the crater rim during eruptions. However, the most destructive events occur when the crater rim breaks, causing a massive outpouring of water; such an event killed 151 people in 1953. This study aims to reveal the risk of future lahars by understanding the strength of the rock that composes the crater rim and analyzing possible scenarios that could lead to its collapse. This is critical for mitigating the risk to climbers and skiers on the volcano?s flanks, which on busy days can reach over 10,000 people. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Ben Kennedy, a leading researcher in experimental volcanology, at the University of Canterbury in Christchurch, New Zealand.

The objectives for the study are: (1) understand how the stress and strain of the rock composing the crater rim evolve during strain events, and; (2) determine the probability of crater rim failure using computational models. Specifically, seismic waves will be pulsed through rock samples during cyclic stressing experiments to determine the material?s susceptibility to damage during repeated loading events (e.g. crater lake water level rise and earthquakes). These material properties will then be used in 2- and 3-D numerical models to simulate such events. This will reveal the most influential variables in crater rim stability, the scenarios in which the crater rim may collapse, and the size and direction of possible future lahars. For people living in the vicinity of active volcanoes prone to lahars, such as Mount Rainier (USA), understanding volcanic material behavior can improve hazard monitoring, ultimately reducing risks associated with dangerous volcanic phenomena.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research analyzed the stability of the crater rim of the active Mt. Ruapehu volcano, located on the north island of New Zealand. Due to the presence of a lake in the crater, the collapse of the crater rim can lead to a massive outpouring of water, creating deadly mud flows (lahars) as other material is incorporated along the flow path; such an event occurred recently in both 1953 and 2007, resulting in 151 deaths in 1953. Stability of Mt. Ruapehu’s crater rim was analyzed using numerical modeling and existing rock mechanical data to understand the probability of a collapse during different triggering events such as earthquakes, eruptive activity, and water table level change. Numerical modeling shows that under current conditions, the crater rim would likely remain stable during realistic seismic events. It is possible that a large volcano-tectonic earthquake associated with an eruption could cause the crater rim to fail, but such an event is unlikely. Erosion of the strong lava cap at the summit due to eruptive activity or water undercutting at the crater rim outlet could result in water saturation of weaker layers beneath the strong lava cap, reducing the strength of the crater rim over time. Careful monitoring of such a scenario could provide forewarning of such an event, greatly reducing the risks associated with a collapse and subsequent lahar event.
